Ten years ago the failure of Lehman Brothers exposed how capital here the world
Had been towards risk households have bought homes they thought could never go down in price and banks had made loans they thought would never defaults than repackaged image securities to make them seem risk lists
With time even the deepest traumas wear off and there are signs that risk taking is returning though in different forms from before more from Greg is chief economics commentator at the wall Street Journal Greg how do you see it
Got to Christ basically because uh everybody became somewhat blind to the president of risk weather was bankers who thought that these loans could ever to fall to her home buyers who taught their homes would never decline in price they essentially didn't realize this
They were taking on [noise] and ever since all of us bankers investors and we as individuals have really tried to avoid a repeat by also limiting are exposure risk whether it's in regulations or attitudes towards risk such as what we want to buy stocks and what type of stocks we buy
And I think that helps explain the kind of economy we've had in the last ten years it's been very stable growth because we haven't had a lot of ah you know boom about sort of crises [laughter] but it's also been very muted growth because you don't get the kind of investment of risk taking a firm which long term prosperity is born
That's interesting do your own household and investors are much ... of risk what's the uh ... what some of the other evidence that you've seen
Well housing is a very good example I used to be that aren't blue year we'd build one and a half million new homes
And its expansion so far it's more like a million and there are several rates for that one is that well I'm wearing aging country so maybe fewer people need homes
But also regulators have made it harder to get mortgages so that's limited who couldn't buy a house [laughter] I and also I think young families young adults are also more hesitant to make that size of a commitment and you can see that in their own behavior they live at home with their parents longer they take longer to have to get married and longer to have children
Wow what kind of a ripple effect I guess does that have

You don't have as many people going to start their own business Bartlett because it's harder to get the loan you know he used to turn to a home equity loan to start your new business [laughter] those are harder to get but I also think people are at an age and it sort of a psyche that it's just something they don't want to do [noise]
Sure you have your ... Beatles here and you must there but it really kind of the exception you know it seems that if even if you look at Silicon Valley [laughter]
What people want is to not start the next Google and Facebook but to be bought by the next Google or Facebook level of new businesses being formed does actually historically quite low and I think it's troublesome I mean essentially that people need to take risks to come up with a new or a better product and if nobody wants to take risks we're going to kind of stagnate
For speaking with ... chief economics commentator at the wall Street Journal he's written a piece titled the financial crisis a crisis made us afraid of risk

As well and some of the pessimism that we've noticed for the last eight or nine years has worn off [laughter]
